"In the fall of 2001, Hewlett-Packard announced a momentous $25 billion merger with Compaq."
This has to be on of the worst corporate decisions of all time. Anyone could go to the Computer show in Las Vegas, buy motherboards equal to or better then Compaq, without all the proprietary plug ins required for a Compaq system.

Just about any small company could produce a decent desktop computer. HP was a leader in inkjet printers at the time. But their best business was in electronic and medical test equipment. They also made minicomputers, that competed with IBM 360s.

So later they spun off the test equipment business which is now Agilent, which is very profitable. They lost a big part of the R&D engineering, and began the slow decline from one of the worlds great electronic companies, to a middling me too competitor. Then they fired a CEO who is now a VP with Oracle the biggest database producer, led by Larry Ellison, the richest man in California.

Now they think there is money in spinning off remains of Compaq. Who wants it, when there are better systems like ASUS available? Buy a HP computer and you have to use their drivers, it comes with MS Windows configured for their motherboard. Buy an ASUS, Gigabyte, Acer, or others, and use original MS programs, instead of OEM. OEM is cheaper, but support is terrible. HPs support is lousy for that matter.

Not only is Whitman the CEO, but Patricia Russo, who managed to sink Lucent, and almost did in Alcatel is on the BoD.

interesting comment and summary of the evolution of pluralism in the U.S.; begs the question, did the economic elite take control, or did we in the middle class give it to them as a result of our getting too comfortable and our lack of involvement in our own government over the years?

At the risk of over simplification The United States is a Republic with a centralized federal government structured to work within a framework of institutions governed by democratic popular pluralism. However, as the overall economic system inexorably became more advanced, unstable and fragile the primary financial paradigm devolved from long term capital investment and hedging to short term leveraged speculation and ponzi schemas.

Increasingly, the regulatory regime enacted after the Great Depression, which temporarily provided a somewhat stable financial system for fifty years, became more and more of an impediment to large capital asset holders and financial intermediaries. The end of cheap oil and other price inflation primary of industrial commodities destabilized and undermined Capital's long run inflation adjusted returns.

In consequence, the divsion of net national income was skewed more and more to capital versus labor inputs via globalization, legislative and regulatory capture. The skewing of national income was temporarily masked by the increase of two income households among the middle class and two assets bubbles; one in technology equities and most recently, real estate. The Great Recession and Meltdown simply laid bare the long term erosion of economic and political power of the middle class.

Popular democratic pluralism has been in decline since Reagan. The ascendancy of economic elite domination is the cause not superficial political gridlock.

This is what people do not realize about the "compromise" with respect to derivatives:

Whether such derivatives exist in a FDIC insured institution or not, the tax payer is "on the hook" for a financial debacle. AIG was not a FDIC insured institution, yet it required $182 billion in taxpayer funds in a bailout.

Saving AIG was required to avert a larger economic tragedy as the derivatives that hedged losses on collateralized debt obligations linked to mortgages would have bankrupted a wide variety of entities who had hedged their exposure and spread the crisis further.

Instead of being angry at Congress for doing something that just recognizes reality, you should save your cynicism for the former AIG CEO suing because the terms of his bailout from the US taxpayer were not generous enough.

That is the outrageous display of gall and greed and corruption.

It is quite possible, or even probable, that in the Pope's "book", heaven is not a fairy tale at all, and that he was speaking as truthfully as he could to this child.

How nice that the Pope made a little boy feel better. He does have a knack for that.

But what if a child had asked if Santa would be coming down the chimney? Or if the Tooth Fairy would arrive that night? All are fairy tales in my book, heaven included. And yet here we are debating the topic endlessly ... we are an odd species, aren't we?

With regard to souls, there seems to be only three possibilities which I'll list in order of likelihood:

1. There is no such thing as a soul.
2. Every living thing has a soul.
3. At some arbitrary point in human evolution, someone was born with a soul, but unfortunately his or her parents were soulless.

It would seem that to believe every living thing has a soul, requires one to reexamine the way other species and their habitats are treated by ours, and I would at least welcome the results of that belief even if it's not my own.

Nyhan notes:
"At election time, candidates seduce us with promises to bring America together, ... "
And that is where the canker gnaws because bringing "America together" is nothing more than a fool's errand based on a long standing fallacy.

It is the inhabitants of the nation that cannot and will not ever be "brought together". They simply will never allow it to happen. To do so would require the abandonment of cherished self-centered attitudes and beliefs.
The possibility of being "brought together" is the mighty myth under which we will exist in perpetuity with no solution forthcoming ... ever.
Why do we require someone to do the impossible when we cannot and will not do it for ourselves.

We are a nation of disparate peoples, ideals, inclinations, needs, goals etc. because of our great diversity of origins, ethics, beliefs, ideologies, ethnic, and religious backgrounds.

The great cry to "bring us together" flies in the face of reality and as a result is a monumental waste of time and effort.
The quote attributed to Hillary Clinton is an accurate mockery of this entire belief and myth and impossibility.
Say what you will about her, she is, however, very much in tune with reality and all its vagaries.
She also said about Obama when he received the party nomination for President - "He doesn't know what he is up against." - a prescient remark if there ever was one.

I think there are a couple of problems with that. I have friends for example who are faculty. To work from home when they had a newborn, they hired a nanny so that they could actually work while they were at home. Even for jobs that provide some time and flexibility, the work still needs to be done, and I can't see how someone could focus on a child and work--even if they were at home. There would still be a need for child care. Also, even for the case of an older child, there is still the question of what fraction of jobs can be done working from home. In some professions (say for example medicine, or say for example administrative support) in person interactions are required. Even for positions where people could work from home often require a significant amount of overlap with coworkers.

I think a more sensible policy is some variation of the French solution where some period of paid leave of 6 months (a bit arbitrary) is given to a family when they have a newborn and that there is good public affordable daycare to encourage women to come back to the workforce. The challenge seems to be avoiding the "mommy" tracking that occurs later...
